Heading: Victim type
Value: All but one of his victims were prostitutes and/or engaged in that lifestyle with use of drugs. The victim who was not a prostitute was a mentally ill woman in Kansas City who was known to frequently walk the streets and accept rides from strangers.

Value: Strangled, most victims had pieces of clothing stuffed in their mouths and ligature marks on their necks. Some of the victims were posed.

Heading: Left at scene, no attempt to hide
Moved, no attempt to hide
Value: Yes, on the occasions when the body was posed, bodies found in various places (abandoned van, a field, a parking lot and a snow drift)

Heading: Sentencing
Value: The prosecution is seeking the death penalty, the trial is scheduled for October 2006. On August 24, 2006 the defense requested the trial be postponed until March 2007. Gilyard is facing ten counts of first-degree murder and two counts of capital murder.

Heading: Date convicted
Value: The trial was originally scheduled for October 2006, however, a motion was made on August 24, 2006 to postpone the trial until March 5, 2007 due to budget cuts in the state public defender system. The motion was granted. Throughout pre-trial hearing attorneys have debated several issues surrounding the case, including the possibility of eliminating the death penalty. A key piece of evidence was prematurely destroyed by the Kansas City Police Department, a blue coat with blood stains. Because of this the defense has requested that the prosecutions death penalty motion be relinquished. The prosecution is seeking multiple trials with the first one solely focusing on five killings that occurred between 1986 and 1987.

Heading: Did killer plead NGRI?
Value: No, he simply plead not guilty

Heading: Name and state of prison
Value: While awaiting trial Gilyard is being held at the Missouri Department of Corrections.
